subject: Improve "get_devices_with_ip" performance
messages: [{'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2021-03-01 10:32:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2021-03-02 07:27:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2021-03-02 19:40:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2021-03-03 09:28:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2021-03-03 13:55:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-01 10:32:15.000000000', 'message': 'Improve "get_devices_with_ip" performance

As reported in LP#1896734, there is a limit in the size of information
that can be transmitted in one single message between an application
and the privsep daemon. The read socket buffer is limited in size;
a message exceeding this size will generate an exception.

In order to limit the amount of information to be sent, this patch
improves the performance of "get_devices_with_ip". In the previous
implementation, the whole list of network devices from a namespace
was retrieved. In some environments, the list of devices could be
so big that the list returned by "privileged.get_link_devices" can
exceed the read buffer size (as reported in the LP bug when the
OVS agent tries to retrieve the list of IP addresses in the system).

Now the function calls "privileged.get_ip_addresses", that returns
a much smaller list. This patch is also reducing the number of system
calls to just one; the previous implementation was retrieving first
the devices link information list (that method was returning a much
bigger blob) and then, per device, retrieving the IP address
information.

Change-Id: I97ada62484023b9833ed12afd68eb4c8d337fd1f
Related-Bug: #1896734
(cherry picked from commit a6cdf273c06a3bba713d7b8d0ef3a9b71b0ffc57)
'}]
commit_message:
Improve "get_devices_with_ip" performance

As reported in LP#1896734, there is a limit in the size of information
that can be transmitted in one single message between an application
and the privsep daemon. The read socket buffer is limited in size;
a message exceeding this size will generate an exception.

In order to limit the amount of information to be sent, this patch
improves the performance of "get_devices_with_ip". In the previous
implementation, the whole list of network devices from a namespace
was retrieved. In some environments, the list of devices could be
so big that the list returned by "privileged.get_link_devices" can
exceed the read buffer size (as reported in the LP bug when the
OVS agent tries to retrieve the list of IP addresses in the system).

Now the function calls "privileged.get_ip_addresses", that returns
a much smaller list. This patch is also reducing the number of system
calls to just one; the previous implementation was retrieving first
the devices link information list (that method was returning a much
bigger blob) and then, per device, retrieving the IP address
information.

Change-Id: I97ada62484023b9833ed12afd68eb4c8d337fd1f
Related-Bug: #1896734
(cherry picked from commit a6cdf273c06a3bba713d7b8d0ef3a9b71b0ffc57)

commit_message:
Add administrator docs for distributed-import

This adds some text to the documentation about configuring the import
mechanism, including details about shared vs. local staging
directories. It also clarifies that *all* import methods require the
staging directory to be configured, as well as cleans up some
single-store-specific wording in this area.

Related to blueprint distributed-image-import

Change-Id: I726abe5d1104510e8da0e94f90f2b36d43b82cbe

subject: Don't uninstall kexec-tools
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4571, 'name': 'Steve Baker', 'email': 'sbaker@redhat.com', 'username': 'steve-stevebaker'}, {'_account_id': 9592, 'name': 'wes hayutin', 'email': 'whayutin@redhat.com', 'username': 'weshayutin'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24245, 'name': 'Harald Jensås', 'email': 'hjensas@redhat.com', 'username': 'harald.jensas'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2021-02-25 02:33:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-02-25 21:15:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2021-02-26 03:52:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Thinking about this some more, removing kexec-tools is a security hardening action, so maybe leaving it is not ideal.

Other options I can think of to handle this:
- convert this into a script which runs in finalize after 50-dracut-regenerate
- changing the behaviour of uninstall to leave "unused" dependencies'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-03-01 22:13:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> Thinking about this some more, removing kexec-tools is a security hardening action, so maybe leaving it is not ideal.
> 
> Other options I can think of to handle this:
> - convert this into a script which runs in finalize after 50-dracut-regenerate
> - changing the behaviour of uninstall to leave "unused" dependencies

Would it work to simply add here:

dracut-network:
  uninstall: False'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2021-03-04 00:29:33.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

It looks like only dracut-049-95.git20200804 is affected by this. dracut-network-049-70 which is available in the recommended eus repos works fine. Lets revisit when this becomes an issue for recommended repos'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-25 02:33:59.000000000', 'message': "Don't uninstall kexec-tools

This has the side-effect of uninstalling dracut-network on rhel-8,
which causes dracut to fail during finalise because of the broken
legacy-network module.

Change-Id: I03ca096ce69689a26fddc404279a8b003c971c15
"}]
commit_message:
Don't uninstall kexec-tools

This has the side-effect of uninstalling dracut-network on rhel-8,
which causes dracut to fail during finalise because of the broken
legacy-network module.

Change-Id: I03ca096ce69689a26fddc404279a8b003c971c15

[{'created': '2021-02-24 15:41:09.000000000', 'message': "FC: Fix not flushing on detach

When doing multipathed Fibre Channel we may end up not flushing the
volume when disconnecting it if didn't find a multipath when doing
the connection.

The issue is caused by the `connect_volume` call returning a real path
instead of a symlink and us passing the wrong device_info to the
_remove_devices method, which makes the disconnect code incorrectly
identify when a multipath was used to decide whether to do a flush or
not.

This patch fixes these things in order to flush the individual path when
necessary.

Closes-Bug: #1897787
Change-Id: Ie3266c81b3c6bb5a2c213a12410539d404d1febe
(cherry picked from commit 1432c369fb49b7359bd9d48af24133f5c4019402)
(cherry picked from commit 3adcb40678ee771d6701e798f1f50ebce8b63aa3)
(cherry picked from commit 1e7ad8b7a44c88b484b034d8933b8a2f3bbc9d52)
"}]
commit_message:
FC: Fix not flushing on detach

When doing multipathed Fibre Channel we may end up not flushing the
volume when disconnecting it if didn't find a multipath when doing
the connection.

The issue is caused by the `connect_volume` call returning a real path
instead of a symlink and us passing the wrong device_info to the
_remove_devices method, which makes the disconnect code incorrectly
identify when a multipath was used to decide whether to do a flush or
not.

This patch fixes these things in order to flush the individual path when
necessary.

Closes-Bug: #1897787
Change-Id: Ie3266c81b3c6bb5a2c213a12410539d404d1febe
(cherry picked from commit 1432c369fb49b7359bd9d48af24133f5c4019402)
(cherry picked from commit 3adcb40678ee771d6701e798f1f50ebce8b63aa3)
(cherry picked from commit 1e7ad8b7a44c88b484b034d8933b8a2f3bbc9d52)

commit_message:
Create a container for Unbound DNS resolver

This patch sets up TripleO to create a container for the Unbound
DNS resolver. This will be used with Designate deployments to
provide DNS resolver services to the deployment and neutron.

Change-Id: Ifccee277393cc9ab095d1785216d3dacfbf3c5ce
(cherry picked from commit 96d3c1fa0613af6ce8fdef01d5f9d696da993aec)

[{'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-01-08 18:19:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-01-08 18:28:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I thought I would help move this along a bit by PoC'ing the approach, since I hadn't seen any code for that yet and the spec is still pending (apologies if I missed it). I just used an extra_properties key for expediency, but obviously we can replace that with a formal one, pending the outcome of that discussion on the spec.

This does work locally with roughly these steps:

* Start with a normal devstack
* Start another g-api instance on a different port that it does not know about (and thus will never send requests to). Configure direct_url= on that one to point to the right host/port
* Create an image and stage its data directly to the second worker (glance --os-image-url=$url image-stage ...)
* Run glance image-import normally, which hits the regular worker and proxies to the other one"}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-01-08 21:30:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck unrelated failures'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2021-02-01 17:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-02-01 18:21:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

As we discussed in the meeting, I would very much like to see this be a separate patch on top of my original one, with just the location changes. That will make it easier to actually suss out the differences.

This patch includes not only the properties->locations changes, but also a bunch of other unrelated or supporting refactors (which may very well be good), but which distract from and confuse the actual implementation. They make this patch much larger in scope than it should be, which is *just* the proxy-to-stage-host behavior. It looks to me like you're adding a big special case to the storing of the image in the staging store, but it's hard for me to tell if that is really just part of your refactor, or actually necessary for the use of locations to store the staging host metadata entry. I'm also not sure if the refactors are required to use the locations for storing the staging host or not.

I see no new or changed tests for all the refactors. I suspect that means they're not currently tested, or not thoroughly enough. I would expect to see added test coverage to go along with them to prove that they work and are equivalent to what we have now. I also see no tests for the actual use of locations for storing the staging host, but it is also hard to separate the new staging host stuff from the refactors to even know which bits would/should be separately tested.

So, in summary, I would very much like to see:
 1. The refactors be split into separate patches with tests that we can potentially merge ahead of
    the proxying change.
 2. My PS9 restored as PS11, and with your proposed locations changes as a patch on top, and tests to
    show that we are using them properly.
 3. You orphaned the patch above this one that enables the additional worker and enables the tempest 
    test. The previous patch was fully tested in devstack and tempest, and I don't anticipate 
    approving this approach until we see that test also passing on this one. So please either rebase 
    that on top of your proposed changes patch, or clone it to go above yours to enable the test.

It would have been easier if the refactors and the proposed locations changes were kept separate from the beginning, but let me know if you need help splitting those from PS9 and I'll be glad to assist (or just do it for you), because I think it's important."}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2021-02-01 20:56:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(8 comments)

> Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1
> 
> (6 comments)
> 
> As we discussed in the meeting, I would very much like to see this be a separate patch on top of my original one, with just the location changes. That will make it easier to actually suss out the differences.

Like discussed in IRC, getting between delta, and the individual approaches in gerrit is pretty easy and makes it much faster to compare. 
> 
> This patch includes not only the properties->locations changes, but also a bunch of other unrelated or supporting refactors (which may very well be good), but which distract from and confuse the actual implementation. They make this patch much larger in scope than it should be, which is *just* the proxy-to-stage-host behavior. It looks to me like you're adding a big special case to the storing of the image in the staging store, but it's hard for me to tell if that is really just part of your refactor, or actually necessary for the use of locations to store the staging host metadata entry. I'm also not sure if the refactors are required to use the locations for storing the staging host or not.

And this is exactly the attitude why I said the quick and easy is not good enough. You wanted to take the scope of the spec, which should pretty clearly underline that the approach explained is there to clean up lots of the technical debt we left behind by merging the image import in the shape it was. Yet you took the "new and shiny" and strapped it on with some bubblegum and duct tape to call it good. You wanted to see PoC to understand _why_ this approach was so important that the duct tape and bubblegum wasn't good enough to tick the box. Well all the refactoring around staging and import flows are the reason.

> 
> I see no new or changed tests for all the refactors. I suspect that means they're not currently tested, or not thoroughly enough. I would expect to see added test coverage to go along with them to prove that they work and are equivalent to what we have now. I also see no tests for the actual use of locations for storing the staging host, but it is also hard to separate the new staging host stuff from the refactors to even know which bits would/should be separately tested.

Yeah lets worry about the tests when we're past of "PoC for you to understand the concept of the design".

> 
> So, in summary, I would very much like to see:
>  1. The refactors be split into separate patches with tests that we can potentially merge ahead of
>     the proxying change.

I'm open to suggestions of how/if this should be split after we have the spec what we're doing agreed.

>  2. My PS9 restored as PS11, and with your proposed locations changes as a patch on top, and tests to
>     show that we are using them properly.

Ditto, we can look testing and rewriting this as it's own change once we've got past the spec phase of the work.

>  3. You orphaned the patch above this one that enables the additional worker and enables the tempest 
>     test. The previous patch was fully tested in devstack and tempest, and I don't anticipate 
>     approving this approach until we see that test also passing on this one. So please either rebase 
>     that on top of your proposed changes patch, or clone it to go above yours to enable the test.

Ditto, changes to tempest are implementation details, we'll get there once we get past the spec phase. 
> 
> It would have been easier if the refactors and the proposed locations changes were kept separate from the beginning, but let me know if you need help splitting those from PS9 and I'll be glad to assist (or just do it for you), because I think it's important.

It would have been easier if you would have implemented your PoC based on the design written in the spec or focussed explaining your reasons in the spec rather than making quick and dirty implementation and expecting the spec to be aligned with that.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-02-01 22:27:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(6 comments)

> Like discussed in IRC, getting between delta, and the individual approaches in gerrit is pretty easy and makes it much faster to compare. 

Also like I said in IRC, it's not easier, both because you're changing more than needs to be changed just to support the proxy behavior, and because you bring in all the rebase noise with this.

> And this is exactly the attitude why I said the quick and easy is not good enough. You wanted to take the scope of the spec, which should pretty clearly underline that the approach explained is there to clean up lots of the technical debt we left behind by merging the image import in the shape it was. Yet you took the "new and shiny" and strapped it on with some bubblegum and duct tape to call it good. You wanted to see PoC to understand _why_ this approach was so important that the duct tape and bubblegum wasn't good enough to tick the box. Well all the refactoring around staging and import flows are the reason.

For what it's worth, when I wrote this (bubble gum tested and duct tape validated) implementation, the spec still said we were doing this all over a RabbitMQ fanout, and called for storing the url in an unspecified database field: "this approach will require additional expanding migration to our database". Nothing in the spec at that point about storing them in locations:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance-specs/+/763574/1/specs/wallaby/approved/glance/distributed-image-import.rst

It sounds like there's another lite spec's worth of work here to finish the import implementation's use of the staging store, which appears to be good cleanup, but it's separate from this proxy effort, IMHO. It will be very helpful to examine that in isolation, where we can test for things like whether or not having a location with the image being inactive and without a size breaks anything. If it does, then there's more work to be done to fix it, and/or more discussion to be had to decide if it's worth it.

> Yeah lets worry about the tests when we're past of "PoC for you to understand the concept of the design".

Ack, fair enough.

> I'm open to suggestions of how/if this should be split after we have the spec what we're doing agreed.

IMHO, the split should be one or more patches to refactor the use of the store to image.set_data(staging=True), separate from this distributed import implementation.

I think I can see the metadata bits of the store location as a sufficient replacement for the properties (although I still don't think it's *better*), but it's hard to tell at what cost that really comes, until we know what amount of those store-related changes will and won't pass tests. Needing to have the data model insert a URL into the thing right before it shoves it into the database is another layering thing I'd personally try to avoid. The URL by which the API worker is accessible is API business. If we make the data model assume it, then it becomes harder to do things like split out the backend into a worker thread, process, or RPC minion.

That said, if we test and land the staging store refactors, then the "which metadata blob does this use to store the url" question becomes much less important.'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2021-02-01 23:06:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> That said, if we test and land the staging store refactors, then the "which metadata blob does this use to store the url" question becomes much less important.

I think this very bit here got me to understand the fundamental difference of thinking we're having about this patch. I think this might help, let me know if you agree with my analysis:

For you this is a quick and simple "we need to proxy an API call" nothing super special on that, lets put a note stored somewhere commonly available who needs to deal with it and move on.

For me "putting that note somewhere" part was immediate red flag that we're not tracking customer data properly. Not a news, we have bunch of NOTEs and TODOs across the code about this, but I did not see this as problem of needing to proxy an API call, I saw this as data tracking and leaking issue, which if fixed right will conveniently give us what we need to also proxy that call to the right place with pretty little addition to that data tracking. Since we discussed about "just proxying the request to correct node" in PTG I've never thought this as an issue of proxying the call to right place but the fact that we didn't know already what the right place was. Thus also when writing the spec, I approached it from the data perspective not from the perspective of "What should we do with this request we just got but can't handle ourselves". I'd say I've been pushing more details on the prerequisites than the feature itself.

I totally agree btw. Once we know where that blop of customer data is we need to deal with your proxy code is, not specifically attached, nice layer onto that.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-02-02 00:11:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> I think this very bit here got me to understand the fundamental difference of thinking we're having about this patch. I think this might help, let me know if you agree with my analysis:
> 
> For you this is a quick and simple "we need to proxy an API call" nothing super special on that, lets put a note stored somewhere commonly available who needs to deal with it and move on.

Yes, for me, this patch should be the proxy only. That is the only thing related to being able to use import without shared storage between the API nodes that a user can or should see to consider this implemented/fixed. That's the scope of the patch, as laid out in the commit message, and it's also the only thing called out in the "problem description" part of the spec.

As I said in my comments on the spec, since that "note" should only need to live for a few minutes in normal situations, it's wholly unimportant where it goes, so long as it does not expose anything to the user that it shouldn't, nor get lost or be difficult to look up again when we need it. That was my original concern with adding a field to the database to store this transient thing for a brief period, as well as my concern over needing to block this whole effort on any changes required to start recording a location for the staging images. I have not yet heard any concrete reasoning for why putting it in an extra_property is not reasonable (other than the quota issue, which was already a problem and for which I have provided a general fix).

What I don't want to do is block this thing any longer. If the store locations thing was done today and there was a layering-appropriate way to get the url into the location metadata, then I'd be fine doing that. I can see the glimmer of that future in the changes you've made here, but there are still things to discuss I think (like the layering concern of who owns the url, and whether or not any of those changes might confuse a client).

I do not think that using an os_glance property in the interim is harmful. Even if the location stuff landed next cycle, it would be trivial to honor both for a single cycle to avoid upgrade issues. As noted multiple times I also don't think it's harmful permanently, but I think you're assuming a future where having it in locations benefits the proxy *and* something else, which is fine.
 
> For me "putting that note somewhere" part was immediate red flag that we're not tracking customer data properly. Not a news, we have bunch of NOTEs and TODOs across the code about this, but I did not see this as problem of needing to proxy an API call, I saw this as data tracking and leaking issue, which if fixed right will conveniently give us what we need to also proxy that call to the right place with pretty little addition to that data tracking. Since we discussed about "just proxying the request to correct node" in PTG I've never thought this as an issue of proxying the call to right place but the fact that we didn't know already what the right place was. Thus also when writing the spec, I approached it from the data perspective not from the perspective of "What should we do with this request we just got but can't handle ourselves". I'd say I've been pushing more details on the prerequisites than the feature itself.

Okay, I'm still confused about the confusion I guess, because the spec never included much about the data model in its original form. I also don't understand what of the os_glance-based approach is likely to leak or lose track of anything (other than what can already be lost today, as noted by the web-download data leak discussion). However, I'm happy to believe that this held other special meaning for you beyond solving the title problem, especially if it means we can split the two efforts apart :)

> I totally agree btw. Once we know where that blop of customer data is we need to deal with your proxy code is, not specifically attached, nice layer onto that.

Okay, but I'm not sure where this leaves us, though. Maybe you could explain where you see things going from here after this realization? Given where we are in the cycle, how long this code has been waiting, as well as how long this problem has gone unsolved, I'd still like to see us merge the original version of this tested and working implementation (modulo the bikeshedding about the config option name of *course*).

I'd like to review the store and location changes, fully understand the benefit of using a glance store for the staging area, as well as the motivation behind further crystalizing their relationship, and provide input into the decisions about who sets things like the url in metadata. I'd like to do that...separate from this proxy implementation. In IRC some days ago you made it sound like doing those store changes would never happen if not part of this, but I'm more than happy to commit to reviewing the changes and participating in that discussion to help make sure it does not get ignored.

I would be happy to split the proxy stuff out of your spec into a separate one (as long as that doesn't present a paperwork problem for getting it done this cycle) and let you focus on a spec and implementation of the staging store changes, if that helps. Also happy to see the spec stripped down to just the proxy stuff in support of the "problem description" that it already lays out, and follow that with a spec to address the store issues you see.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2021-02-02 07:27:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> >  3. You orphaned the patch above this one that enables the additional worker and enables the tempest 
> >     test. The previous patch was fully tested in devstack and tempest, and I don't anticipate 
> >     approving this approach until we see that test also passing on this one. So please either rebase 
> >     that on top of your proposed changes patch, or clone it to go above yours to enable the test.
> 
> Ditto, changes to tempest are implementation details, we'll get there once we get past the spec phase. 
> > 
> > It would have been easier if the refactors and the proposed locations changes were kept separate from the beginning, but let me know if you need help splitting those from PS9 and I'll be glad to assist (or just do it for you), because I think it's important.
> 
> It would have been easier if you would have implemented your PoC based on the design written in the spec or focussed explaining your reasons in the spec rather than making quick and dirty implementation and expecting the spec to be aligned with that.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2021-02-02 07:33:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> Patch Set 10:
> 
> > I think this very bit here got me to understand the fundamental difference of thinking we're having about this patch. I think this might help, let me know if you agree with my analysis:
> > 
> > For you this is a quick and simple "we need to proxy an API call" nothing super special on that, lets put a note stored somewhere commonly available who needs to deal with it and move on.
> 
> Yes, for me, this patch should be the proxy only. That is the only thing related to being able to use import without shared storage between the API nodes that a user can or should see to consider this implemented/fixed. That's the scope of the patch, as laid out in the commit message, and it's also the only thing called out in the "problem description" part of the spec.
> 
> As I said in my comments on the spec, since that "note" should only need to live for a few minutes in normal situations, it's wholly unimportant where it goes, so long as it does not expose anything to the user that it shouldn't, nor get lost or be difficult to look up again when we need it. That was my original concern with adding a field to the database to store this transient thing for a brief period, as well as my concern over needing to block this whole effort on any changes required to start recording a location for the staging images. I have not yet heard any concrete reasoning for why putting it in an extra_property is not reasonable (other than the quota issue, which was already a problem and for which I have provided a general fix).
> 
> What I don't want to do is block this thing any longer. If the store locations thing was done today and there was a layering-appropriate way to get the url into the location metadata, then I'd be fine doing that. I can see the glimmer of that future in the changes you've made here, but there are still things to discuss I think (like the layering concern of who owns the url, and whether or not any of those changes might confuse a client).
> 
> I do not think that using an os_glance property in the interim is harmful. Even if the location stuff landed next cycle, it would be trivial to honor both for a single cycle to avoid upgrade issues. As noted multiple times I also don't think it's harmful permanently, but I think you're assuming a future where having it in locations benefits the proxy *and* something else, which is fine.
>  
> > For me "putting that note somewhere" part was immediate red flag that we're not tracking customer data properly. Not a news, we have bunch of NOTEs and TODOs across the code about this, but I did not see this as problem of needing to proxy an API call, I saw this as data tracking and leaking issue, which if fixed right will conveniently give us what we need to also proxy that call to the right place with pretty little addition to that data tracking. Since we discussed about "just proxying the request to correct node" in PTG I've never thought this as an issue of proxying the call to right place but the fact that we didn't know already what the right place was. Thus also when writing the spec, I approached it from the data perspective not from the perspective of "What should we do with this request we just got but can't handle ourselves". I'd say I've been pushing more details on the prerequisites than the feature itself.
> 
> Okay, I'm still confused about the confusion I guess, because the spec never included much about the data model in its original form. I also don't understand what of the os_glance-based approach is likely to leak or lose track of anything (other than what can already be lost today, as noted by the web-download data leak discussion). However, I'm happy to believe that this held other special meaning for you beyond solving the title problem, especially if it means we can split the two efforts apart :)
> 
> > I totally agree btw. Once we know where that blop of customer data is we need to deal with your proxy code is, not specifically attached, nice layer onto that.
> 
> Okay, but I'm not sure where this leaves us, though. Maybe you could explain where you see things going from here after this realization? Given where we are in the cycle, how long this code has been waiting, as well as how long this problem has gone unsolved, I'd still like to see us merge the original version of this tested and working implementation (modulo the bikeshedding about the config option name of *course*).
> 
> I'd like to review the store and location changes, fully understand the benefit of using a glance store for the staging area, as well as the motivation behind further crystalizing their relationship, and provide input into the decisions about who sets things like the url in metadata. I'd like to do that...separate from this proxy implementation. In IRC some days ago you made it sound like doing those store changes would never happen if not part of this, but I'm more than happy to commit to reviewing the changes and participating in that discussion to help make sure it does not get ignored.
> 
> I would be happy to split the proxy stuff out of your spec into a separate one (as long as that doesn't present a paperwork problem for getting it done this cycle) and let you focus on a spec and implementation of the staging store changes, if that helps. Also happy to see the spec stripped down to just the proxy stuff in support of the "problem description" that it already lays out, and follow that with a spec to address the store issues you see.


Went through all the discussion, lengthy but interesting one.
Even though this is just a PoC, +1 for splitting the patches
1. location change patch
2. refactoring patch (change is store code to use location staging change)
3. proxy call patch

This will help all the reviewers to understand it better.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2021-02-02 08:22:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)

> 
> I think this very bit here got me to understand the fundamental difference of thinking we're having about this patch. I think this might help, let me know if you agree with my analysis:
> 
> For you this is a quick and simple "we need to proxy an API call" nothing super special on that, lets put a note stored somewhere commonly available who needs to deal with it and move on.
> 
> For me "putting that note somewhere" part was immediate red flag that we're not tracking customer data properly. Not a news, we have bunch of NOTEs and TODOs across the code about this, but I did not see this as problem of needing to proxy an API call, I saw this as data tracking and leaking issue, which if fixed right will conveniently give us what we need to also proxy that call to the right place with pretty little addition to that data tracking. Since we discussed about "just proxying the request to correct node" in PTG I've never thought this as an issue of proxying the call to right place but the fact that we didn't know already what the right place was. Thus also when writing the spec, I approached it from the data perspective not from the perspective of "What should we do with this request we just got but can't handle ourselves". I'd say I've been pushing more details on the prerequisites than the feature itself.
> 
> I totally agree btw. Once we know where that blop of customer data is we need to deal with your proxy code is, not specifically attached, nice layer onto that.'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2021-02-03 12:51:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-08 18:19:54.000000000', 'message': 'PoC: Distributed image import

This is a very rough PoC of the distributed image import spec. It "works"
in local testing, but it's far from ready. It just demonstrates the
idea enough to test it locally.

The general problem is that image import involves staging the image
data before the actual import. That happens on one worker, which may
or may not be the same worker that receives the import request.

The general idea of this approach to address the problem is that
when a worker stages the image, it records its direct url on the
image. When the import request comes in, any other host will
proxy that HTTP request direct to the original host instead of
trying to do the import itself.

This still needs (at least):

 * Fixing tests of course
 * Some way to test this easily in devstack and CI
 * Protection of the os_glance_stage_host, or
 * ...formalizing the staging host into a dedicated attribute
 * Handling of the case where we can't call to the original host

Change-Id: I12daccb43c535b579c22f9d0742039b2ab42e929
'}, {'created': '2021-01-08 21:46:30.000000000', 'message': 'PoC: Distributed image import

commit_message:
Distributed image import

This implements distributed image import support, which addresses
the problem when one API worker has staged the image and another
receives the import request.

The general approach is that when a worker stages the image, it
records its self-reference URL in the image's extra_properties.  When
the import request comes in, any other host will proxy that HTTP
request direct to the original host instead of trying to do the import
itself.

Implements: blueprint distributed-image-import

Change-Id: I12daccb43c535b579c22f9d0742039b2ab42e929

subject: Bump pylint to 2.6.0
messages:
[{'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2020-08-18 12:53:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2020-09-01 14:57:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-09-04 01:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2020-09-04 14:46:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The pylint job isn't actually running."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2020-09-04 14:55:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I wonder: do we still need pylint? pep8 runs flake8. I see various flames on the Internet about which is the best one, so not sure.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-09-04 16:23:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I wonder: do we still need pylint? pep8 runs flake8. I see various
 > flames on the Internet about which is the best one, so not sure.

It's a good question, but I think they cover two different things. Flake8/pep8/pycodestyle is really a coding style linter, making sure code conforms to a certain set of coding guidelines. Pylint goes farther than that and actually does static analysis to look for coding errors with variables being hidden or undeclared and other logic problems. So ideally, I think there is room for both.

That said, we haven't been able to find a good way to get attention those pylint issues. Way back, the pylint job was voting and we would see if there were problems very clearly. Due to so many gotchas with how it does the linting, there are problems it highlights that we are forced to ignore. So the compromise was to make this a non-voting job that only checks on files that are modified. But that results in any errors reported just being ignored.

It may make sense to keep the tox target for this, but remove the zuul job. That way, when someone actually cares to look at things, they can run the job locally and inspect the issues reported to see if there is anything that should be fixed. And we would free up some gate resources for jobs that are actually preventing issues from being merged."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2021-02-19 16:48:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2021-02-19 17:33:03.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

(cleaning up from the queue)'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2021-02-19 17:33:32.000000000', 'content': 'Restored'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-02-19 19:32:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Looks good.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2021-03-03 21:54:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Bump pylint to 2.6.0

The current version does not work anymore with the current
testing stack.
Due to the bump, the wrapper needed a few changes
(maybe it could be dropped at some point?

Version 2.3.0 (used by cinder right now) was considered too,
but it requires a specific version of isort:
https://github.com/PyCQA/isort/issues/1273

Change-Id: I07fa32e7f49bde041d101a2d09860d0bc27acda0

commit_message:
Fix AttributeError

As the change [1] changes the attribute name from
'install_tmp' to 'install_dir'.
This needs to be changed in the code as well.
So corrected the attribute name according to change [1]

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/774572

Closes-Bug: bug/1917583
Change-Id: Ibe629c1e8e682d189d258ae843e9756d5f357108

commit_message:
Re-use transport for rpc server

This patch changes the rpc server to re-use
the transport in the same manner as the rpc client.

Story: 2008494
Task: 41752

Change-Id: I93eecacbe45d19c4f73e9a974d60e642e87bbdf0
(cherry picked from commit 672b11950754502d3c724bab0b7e1c5ee3436fd2)

commit_message:
Release final neutron-lib for Wallaby

This proposed a release for neutron-lib to get any final merged changes
out prior to the lib freeze for Wallaby going into effect.

If the team is ready to proceed, please leave a +1 to acknowledge this
release and we will process right away. If the team is working on any
final merges, leave a -1 with some detail on the status and update the
patch with the new commit hash to use when ready.

Patches with no response will be merged by Monday, March 8.

$ git log --oneline --no-merges 2.9.0..698e4c8
698e4c8 Add PLACEMENT_REPORT plugin constant

Signed-off-by: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I2d354656640a34ba31537ac0790d8989fa402aef

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-02 14:37:11.000000000', 'message': 'Ignore python warnings in the fullstack job

If there is too much output produced to the stdout/stderr during the
tests, stestr can hangs and job will then time out.
To avoid that in fullstack job, this patch is doing the same what
was already done for functional job as well - set PYTHONWARNINGS
variable to "ignore" to ignore all warnings and not send them to stdout.
All info really needed to debug tests is still in the tests' logs in
specific directories.

Change-Id: I080381cb8a88a27130ac21c0e27fc915e38bdedd
'}]
commit_message:
Ignore python warnings in the fullstack job

If there is too much output produced to the stdout/stderr during the
tests, stestr can hangs and job will then time out.
To avoid that in fullstack job, this patch is doing the same what
was already done for functional job as well - set PYTHONWARNINGS
variable to "ignore" to ignore all warnings and not send them to stdout.
All info really needed to debug tests is still in the tests' logs in
specific directories.

Change-Id: I080381cb8a88a27130ac21c0e27fc915e38bdedd

commit_message:
Prevent the endless loop in resource listing

There is potential (i.e. bug in older nova
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1721791) for resource listing to
end up in an endless loop. Try preventing this if next marker is same as
marker we have just used.

Change-Id: I5fb9ff1675cef7c4cb5e1f50a9efbbd8efc23900

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-01 10:31:34.000000000', 'message': 'Improve "get_devices_with_ip" performance

As reported in LP#1896734, there is a limit in the size of information
that can be transmitted in one single message between an application
and the privsep daemon. The read socket buffer is limited in size;
a message exceeding this size will generate an exception.

In order to limit the amount of information to be sent, this patch
improves the performance of "get_devices_with_ip". In the previous
implementation, the whole list of network devices from a namespace
was retrieved. In some environments, the list of devices could be
so big that the list returned by "privileged.get_link_devices" can
exceed the read buffer size (as reported in the LP bug when the
OVS agent tries to retrieve the list of IP addresses in the system).

Now the function calls "privileged.get_ip_addresses", that returns
a much smaller list. This patch is also reducing the number of system
calls to just one; the previous implementation was retrieving first
the devices link information list (that method was returning a much
bigger blob) and then, per device, retrieving the IP address
information.

Change-Id: I97ada62484023b9833ed12afd68eb4c8d337fd1f
Related-Bug: #1896734
(cherry picked from commit a6cdf273c06a3bba713d7b8d0ef3a9b71b0ffc57)
'}]
commit_message:
Improve "get_devices_with_ip" performance

As reported in LP#1896734, there is a limit in the size of information
that can be transmitted in one single message between an application
and the privsep daemon. The read socket buffer is limited in size;
a message exceeding this size will generate an exception.

In order to limit the amount of information to be sent, this patch
improves the performance of "get_devices_with_ip". In the previous
implementation, the whole list of network devices from a namespace
was retrieved. In some environments, the list of devices could be
so big that the list returned by "privileged.get_link_devices" can
exceed the read buffer size (as reported in the LP bug when the
OVS agent tries to retrieve the list of IP addresses in the system).

Now the function calls "privileged.get_ip_addresses", that returns
a much smaller list. This patch is also reducing the number of system
calls to just one; the previous implementation was retrieving first
the devices link information list (that method was returning a much
bigger blob) and then, per device, retrieving the IP address
information.

Change-Id: I97ada62484023b9833ed12afd68eb4c8d337fd1f
Related-Bug: #1896734
(cherry picked from commit a6cdf273c06a3bba713d7b8d0ef3a9b71b0ffc57)

commit_message:
Validate 'server group create --policy' option

We were documenting that some of these policies were only supported with
specific microversions, however, we weren't actually enforcing that,
leading to a poor user experience. Correct this.

Change-Id: Ic3c555226a220efd9b0f27edffccf6c4c95c2747
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Story: #2007727
Task: #39882
(cherry picked from commit ab0b1fe885ee0a210a58008b631521025be7f3eb)

perhaps its a differnet pip version, i was using

ubuntu@numa-1:/opt/repos/nova$ pip3 --version
pip 20.0.2 from /usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/pip (python 3.8)'}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2021-02-23 13:24:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

@Sean so did I, using the latest pip version. Would you guys be ok with skipping the os-brick dependency until we sort out the lower constraints?'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-02-23 13:55:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

ok so my tox env was created before i uipdated pip and was orginally using 

pip 20.2.4 from /opt/repos/nova/.tox/lower-constraints/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pip (python 3.8)

if i pass -r to have it recreate teh enve it uses
pip 20.3.4 from /opt/repos/nova/.tox/lower-constraints/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pip (python 3.8)

and in that case i get the gate failure.

if i then upgrade that to latest pip 

ubuntu@numa-1:/opt/repos/nova$ .tox/lower-constraints/bin/pip install -U pip
Requirement already satisfied: pip in ./.tox/lower-constraints/lib/python3.8/site-packages (20.3.4)
Collecting pip
  Using cached pip-21.0.1-py3-none-any.whl (1.5 MB)
Installing collected packages: pip
  Attempting uninstall: pip
    Found existing installation: pip 20.3.4
    Uninstalling pip-20.3.4:
      Successfully uninstalled pip-20.3.4
Successfully installed pip-21.0.1

and then run it again
tox -v -e  lower-constraints

we also get the same error. as somehow we seam to downgrade pip again 

if i manually upgrade pip and run the same command as tox

/opt/repos/nova/.tox/lower-constraints/bin/python -m pip install -c/opt/repos/nova/lower-constraints.txt -r/opt/repos/nova/test-requirements.txt -r/opt/repos/nova/requirements.txt

then it it gets a slighly different error 

20.3.4 
The conflict is caused by:
    The user requested oslo.i18n>=3.15.3
    castellan 0.16.0 depends on oslo.i18n>=3.15.3
    cursive 0.2.1 depends on oslo.i18n>=2.1.0
    keystonemiddleware 4.20.0 depends on oslo.i18n>=3.15.3
    os-brick 4.2.0 depends on oslo.i18n>=5.0.1

21.0.1

The conflict is caused by:
    bandit 1.1.0 depends on six>=1.9.0
    cryptography 2.7 depends on six>=1.4.1
    cursive 0.2.1 depends on six>=1.9.0
    eventlet 0.26.1 depends on six>=1.10.0
    fixtures 3.0.0 depends on six
    futurist 1.8.0 depends on six>=1.10.0
    gabbi 1.35.0 depends on six
    jsonschema 3.2.0 depends on six>=1.11.0
    keystoneauth1 3.16.0 depends on six>=1.10.0
    keystonemiddleware 4.20.0 depends on six>=1.10.0
    openstacksdk 0.35.0 depends on six>=1.10.0
    os-brick 4.2.0 depends on six>=1.15.0

but if i keep running the same commnad the errro keeps chaing.
so it looks like the new resolver is not deterministic

syncing the deps of an optional lib into a project that uses it makes
all lib deps viral

that is not a maintainable thing to do.

i think the correct way to fix this is to remove any package that is not directly used by nova form the lower constraits list and do the same for all the other libs evenutally.


granted distors are going to thee to fullfile os-brick min versions if they package os-brick and nova which they will but nova does not actully require the same min version as os-brick so im not partically happy with the idea of copying the deps.

it would work but really if we go that rout we have lost most of the usefulness of having per progject lower constratints. we have transtivly ment that lower constratis are now global lower constraits.'}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2021-02-23 14:15:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

> but if i keep running the same commnad the errro keeps chaing.
> so it looks like the new resolver is not deterministic
> 
> syncing the deps of an optional lib into a project that uses it makes
> all lib deps viral
> 
> that is not a maintainable thing to do.
> 
> i think the correct way to fix this is to remove any package that is not directly used by nova form the lower constraits list and do the same for all the other libs evenutally.

Thanks a lot for trying it out. Dropping indirect dependencies is what we did for os-win as well.

> 
> granted distors are going to thee to fullfile os-brick min versions if they package os-brick and nova which they will but nova does not actully require the same min version as os-brick so im not partically happy with the idea of copying the deps.
> 
> it would work but really if we go that rout we have lost most of the usefulness of having per progject lower constratints. we have transtivly ment that lower constratis are now global lower constraits.

Indeed, this has been debated on the ML without reaching a clear consensus, it's more or less up to project maintainers. I think it's out of the scope of this patch, so I'd skip bumping os-brick for now and figure out what to do with the lower constraints afterwards."}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2021-02-23 14:20:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2021-02-24 08:43:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+2

It seems the dep conflict is avoided now.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-02-24 19:43:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

yes since there are no external calls to os-brick in thest anyway that depend on the new version none of the intree code will need the version bump.
when this is deployed you will still need to bump the version but if you are not useing hyperv or ceph then the old version will work fine so im happy with this version'}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2021-02-25 07:04:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-03-01 10:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

> Patch Set 14: Code-Review+1
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> yes since there are no external calls to os-brick in thest anyway that depend on the new version none of the intree code will need the version bump.

This isn't going to work without >=4.2.0 and I56bf09cbd40679eefa5e378c9b36383de89e980c as there is no Windows based RBD connector available.

> when this is deployed you will still need to bump the version but if you are not useing hyperv or ceph then the old version will work fine so im happy with this version

So we are happy to introduce code into the HyperV driver that wouldn't work with the version of os-brick set out in our requirements.txt? I'm pretty confused by this tbh.

I'm still -1 on this until os-brick gets bumped. I appreciate that this is painful and will try to help with this later today and early this week."}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2021-03-02 07:16:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> So we are happy to introduce code into the HyperV driver that wouldn't work with the version of os-brick set out in our requirements.txt? I'm pretty confused by this tbh.
> 
> I'm still -1 on this until os-brick gets bumped. I appreciate that this is painful and will try to help with this later today and early this week.

I think we're running in circles. I did update the lower constraints in patch set 12 but then Sean said that "you should not sync the miniums form os-brick. its an optional depency of nova."

Worth mentioning that there are plenty of optional OpenStack dependencies. For example, Cinder and os-brick use the Python RBD client, yet it's not part of requirements.txt at all. It's the same with tooz backends and db connectors. IMO it doesn't make any sense to keep blocking what should've been a simple patch.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-03-02 11:54:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2021-03-02 11:59:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2

still looks good'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-03-02 12:58:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2021-03-03 10:12:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-03-03 15:48:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

LGTM now with the previous change bump os-brick.'}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2021-03-03 18:37:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

@Lee thanks for cleaning up the lower constraints file. TBH, I did a simple diff between the nova and the os-brick constraints instead of taking them one by one.'}]

commit_message:
hyper-v rbd volume support

Ceph 16 (Pacific) will support attaching RBD images to Windows
hosts as well as Hyper-V VMs [1].

This patch updates the Hyper-V driver so that it may be able to
consume RBD volumes.

We're also updating the os-win requirement to 5.4.0. It should've
been bumped by [2], vms won't spawn without it. Note this introduces no
new or unmet direct or in-direct version dependencies and so is included
as part of this change.

[1] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/pull/33750
[2] Ibe6aff4edeb32208bc9865e9216a7432caddab2b

Implements: blueprint hyperv-rbd

Change-Id: I9ad90817648ca12f80a6b53f6ba728df15cbafab

commit_message:
Add job for keystone functional protection tests

This commit introduces a new check and gate job for keystone to use the
functional RBAC tests in keystone-tempest-plugin.

These tests were derived from keystone's original protection tests, but
they use tempest and they're re-useable for people looking to validate
secure RBAC functionality in their own deployments.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/686305/
Change-Id: I813cff07c20fcba1aaec6a5e68014a2a9eb9462e

This patchset 2 of 3 for OVN driver handling of security-group-logging.
It includes the core changes for this feature.

This implementation also changes the minimum allowed value for the
'rate_limit' attribute in neutron/conf/services/logging.py
Originally, the 'rate_limit' had a min value of 100 and it is now 1
packet per second. The default value remains unchanged, as 100.

[OVN] security group logging support (2 of 2)

This is patchset 2 of 2 for OVN driver handling of security-group-logging.
It includes the core changes and tests for this feature.

This feature requires OVN 20.12 [0] or newer. Functional test will be
skipped for non-supported versions.

Related-Bug: 1468366
Closes-Bug: 1914757

[0]: https://github.com/ovn-org/ovn/commit/880dca99eaf73db7e783999c29386d03c82093bf

Change-Id: Ic86fa70eb34c9b178267b80de1f8883a3ef03e98
Signed-off-by: Flavio Fernandes <flaviof@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Reduce fact gathering

This change updates the default subset to only be the minimum list of
facts for ansible.  In the deployment we need to make sure that we only
collect the minimum amount of facts to perform the tasks at hand rather
than assume we have all the facts.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/775709
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/775708
Related-Bug: #1915761
Change-Id: I61affe32dfc9eacbe514893168397c9b291b8713
(cherry picked from commit 0e81eb420e8974d7815b98e084a94885a1ff1b8b)

commit_message:
Use include task for host prep tasks

Import tasks causes the tasks always to be pulled in and just skipped at
run time. This is terribly slow with more roles even when not running
against those hosts.  A similar effort was applied to the update process
I2eab008ca27546acbd2b1275f07bcca0b84b858c which should also be used
here.

Change-Id: Ibd9bb9f8a4c6a7ce3c6ebd11ce5cf444dde57c33
Related-Bug: #1915761
(cherry picked from commit 73043121e3e05d7ab67503752165da53431a9b34)

commit_message:
Use ansible_facts instead

In order to ANSIBLE_INJECT_FACT_VARS=False we have to use ansible_facts
instead of ansible_* vars. This change switches our distribution and
hostname related items to use ansible_facts instead.

Change-Id: I49a2c42dcbb74671834f312798367f411c819813
Related-Bug: #1915761
(cherry picked from commit 8d1fc85744f6a17415ce8e57afd4e8f1a1f7c922)

commit_message:
Drop service facts usage

This change switches from using service facts to using systemctl
commands to do service checks. This is done to reduce the amount of
memory used as part of the deployment.

Change-Id: I0cd5b24933e50680baefd055d6e68e277ab09315
Related-Bug: #1915761
(cherry picked from commit f9100964f976dd2a590973f313fa6a2449d37b3f)

@Lee: thank you for doing this. It is a lot clearer bump of the os-brick.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-03-02 12:00:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-03-02 12:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

i still think this is not the correct thing to do but we need to have a more in dept conversation around what lower constratis means.

i had tought we agreed to not bump os-brick for the hyperv change since nova did not deirecly use any of the features since tehre is no interface change as part of the bump. but im also not going to try and block this even if i dont agree with it so not + or - 1ing the change.

previously LC tracked the minium version of any direct lib usage ignoring the requirements of our deps. i know some consider that broken and in a sense it was but with the new resolver we are declaring and testing something else which is the min version of all our direct and transitive deps that are co installable. that makes dpes of all libs we consume viral.

for most install of nova this min version bump will not be required and the version bumps for os-brick deps are not required either. this has the effect of raising the oslo.log verion for example when nova does not actully need it when not using hyperv with ceph or is not using os-brick because no cinder.

with the old resolver we would have only increaded the min version of oslo.log when we used the new feature in nova directly not when os-brick used it so for me the meaning fo lower constraints has been entirely redefined by the new resolveer and need to be discussed. previously it was tracking the min api compatibility of our deps not the feature set provided those are two different things where libs have a common driver interface like os-brick.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-03-02 12:54:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

The requirements-check job is failing as these need to be mirrored into requirements.txt, sigh.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-03-02 12:58:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-03-02 12:59:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
requirements.txt: Bump os-brick to 4.2.0

This change simply bumps the version of os-brick required by Nova to
version 4.2.0. This is itself required by
I9ad90817648ca12f80a6b53f6ba728df15cbafab that introduces support for
rbd volumes within the HyperV driver.

After much back and fourth it was decided to bump the required version
of os-brick ahead of that change to allow the following requirements.txt
and lower-constraints.txt changes caused by direct and in-direct
dependency changes to be documented clearly:

os-brick 4.2.0 depends on oslo.log>=4.4.0
\_ oslo-log 4.4.0 depends on python-dateutil>=2.7.0
os-brick 4.2.0 depends on oslo.serialization>=4.0.1
os-brick 4.2.0 depends on pbr>=5.5.0
os-brick 4.2.0 depends on oslo.privsep>=2.4.0
\_ oslo.privsep 2.4.0 depends on msgpack>=0.6.0
os-brick 4.2.0 depends on oslo.service>=2.4.0
os-brick 4.2.0 depends on tenacity>=6.2.0
os-brick 4.2.0 depends on oslo.context>=3.1.1
os-brick 4.2.0 depends on oslo.concurrency>=4.3.0
os-brick 4.2.0 depends on oslo.i18n>=5.0.1
os-brick 4.2.0 depends on six>=1.15.0
os-brick 4.2.0 depends on os-win>=5.1.0

The above changes have been tested with pip 21.0.1 to ensure the new
resolver is happy and that nothing has been missed.

Change-Id: Ic83f3c7c955d0df89d75f700ee4fe2bd7f715794
Implements: blueprint hyperv-rbd

messages: [{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-02-27 18:14:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2021-03-01 17:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2021-03-03 13:58:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-27 18:14:21.000000000', 'message': 'Remove update_initial_state() method from the HA router

This method was intended to check state of the HA router on the
node and update it in the neutron server.
Patch [1] added check of the initial status to the
neutron_keepalived_state_change_monitor process.
It also could cause some race conditions and event which is setting
correct state of the router will be not processed thus router may endup
with two nodes with "primary" state in the Neutron's DB.

Neutron_keepalived_state_change_monitor was notifying agent about
router's initial state only if this state was 'primary'.
Now it will notify agent always to let agent set router's state as
'backup' if needed (that was previously done by this removed
update_initial_state() method).

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/642295

Change-Id: I2cc58c30cf844ee0ecf0611ecdec430086464790
Closes-Bug: #1916022
(cherry picked from commit 0d8ae1576724b196580c9af3782fd3c9e9072bef)
'}]
commit_message:
Remove update_initial_state() method from the HA router

This method was intended to check state of the HA router on the
node and update it in the neutron server.
Patch [1] added check of the initial status to the
neutron_keepalived_state_change_monitor process.
It also could cause some race conditions and event which is setting
correct state of the router will be not processed thus router may endup
with two nodes with "primary" state in the Neutron's DB.

Neutron_keepalived_state_change_monitor was notifying agent about
router's initial state only if this state was 'primary'.
Now it will notify agent always to let agent set router's state as
'backup' if needed (that was previously done by this removed
update_initial_state() method).

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/642295

Change-Id: I2cc58c30cf844ee0ecf0611ecdec430086464790
Closes-Bug: #1916022
(cherry picked from commit 0d8ae1576724b196580c9af3782fd3c9e9072bef)

commit_message:
[OVN] security group logging support (1 of 2)

This is patchset 1 of 2 for OVN driver handling of security-group-logging.
It includes the design documentation for this feature.

Changed a few lines in doc/source/admin/ovn/features.rst, so the extensions
are sorted in alphabetical order.

Related-Bug: 1914757
Partially-implements: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/203509

Change-Id: I95d57613cef3b6892d3a0dd5705e2e8f3386a3a2

messages: [{'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2021-03-03 16:36:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch stable/train.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2021-03-03 20:18:42.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nThe Stein stable branch has been marked EOL here: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/772847 Abandoning this patch.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-03 16:36:37.000000000', 'message': 'Fix neutron subnet lookup ignoring endpoint_type

The recent patch[1] that adds a neutron subnet lookup using the user
context is not honoring the interface/endpoint_type or region_name
settings for neutron in the octavia configuration file.
This is causing problems for deployments that use the "internal"
endpoint for neutron and the current code will always return
the "public" endpoint.
This patch corrects this problem by including those filter
parameters when the neutron endpoint is looked up in keystone.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/726042

Change-Id: I7b8f7c7d653b37395f9a660be67f954a3a6f26d9
Story: 2007863
Task: 40173
(cherry picked from commit 40731e572f2b503a3ccc603642a3721a5ce1cf7a)
(cherry picked from commit 2a18b6cc996e4c64d650c516071c57358681af3b)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix neutron subnet lookup ignoring endpoint_type

The recent patch[1] that adds a neutron subnet lookup using the user
context is not honoring the interface/endpoint_type or region_name
settings for neutron in the octavia configuration file.
This is causing problems for deployments that use the "internal"
endpoint for neutron and the current code will always return
the "public" endpoint.
This patch corrects this problem by including those filter
parameters when the neutron endpoint is looked up in keystone.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/726042

Change-Id: I7b8f7c7d653b37395f9a660be67f954a3a6f26d9
Story: 2007863
Task: 40173
(cherry picked from commit 40731e572f2b503a3ccc603642a3721a5ce1cf7a)
(cherry picked from commit 2a18b6cc996e4c64d650c516071c57358681af3b)

subject: Remove update_initial_state() method from the HA router
messages: [{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-02-27 18:19:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2021-03-01 17:09:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2021-03-03 13:57:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-27 18:19:42.000000000', 'message': 'Remove update_initial_state() method from the HA router

This method was intended to check state of the HA router on the
node and update it in the neutron server.
Patch [1] added check of the initial status to the
neutron_keepalived_state_change_monitor process.
It also could cause some race conditions and event which is setting
correct state of the router will be not processed thus router may endup
with two nodes with "primary" state in the Neutron's DB.

Neutron_keepalived_state_change_monitor was notifying agent about
router's initial state only if this state was 'primary'.
Now it will notify agent always to let agent set router's state as
'backup' if needed (that was previously done by this removed
update_initial_state() method).

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/642295

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/l3/ha_router.py
    neutron/agent/l3/keepalived_state_change.py
    neutron/tests/unit/agent/l3/test_dvr_local_router.py

Change-Id: I2cc58c30cf844ee0ecf0611ecdec430086464790
Closes-Bug: #1916022
(cherry picked from commit 0d8ae1576724b196580c9af3782fd3c9e9072bef)
'}]
commit_message:
Remove update_initial_state() method from the HA router

This method was intended to check state of the HA router on the
node and update it in the neutron server.
Patch [1] added check of the initial status to the
neutron_keepalived_state_change_monitor process.
It also could cause some race conditions and event which is setting
correct state of the router will be not processed thus router may endup
with two nodes with "primary" state in the Neutron's DB.

Neutron_keepalived_state_change_monitor was notifying agent about
router's initial state only if this state was 'primary'.
Now it will notify agent always to let agent set router's state as
'backup' if needed (that was previously done by this removed
update_initial_state() method).

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/642295

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/l3/ha_router.py
    neutron/agent/l3/keepalived_state_change.py
    neutron/tests/unit/agent/l3/test_dvr_local_router.py

Change-Id: I2cc58c30cf844ee0ecf0611ecdec430086464790
Closes-Bug: #1916022
(cherry picked from commit 0d8ae1576724b196580c9af3782fd3c9e9072bef)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-23 14:48:13.000000000', 'message': 'Fix PKCS#11 reinitialization after failure

This patch fixes an error condition where the PCKS#11 object is lost
afte multiple failures from the PKCS#11 device.

Without this patch Barbican can enter an error state where the PKCS11
object is deallocated and is unable to recover returning 500s until the
process is restarted.

Story: 2008649
Task: 41913
Change-Id: Ieab0f152ef307fb9311b92f0ad8bd0032e78269e
'}]
commit_message:
Fix PKCS#11 reinitialization after failure

This patch fixes an error condition where the PCKS#11 object is lost
afte multiple failures from the PKCS#11 device.

Without this patch Barbican can enter an error state where the PKCS11
object is deallocated and is unable to recover returning 500s until the
process is restarted.

Story: 2008649
Task: 41913
Change-Id: Ieab0f152ef307fb9311b92f0ad8bd0032e78269e

commit_message:
pin bundler to 2.2.11

It seems the latest 2.2.12 requires rake>13.0 installed and that
requirement doesn't work well in current our CI jobs.
Let's pin it to the previous version until we resolve the issue.

This change also removes the pin for the very old Ruby version.

Closes-Bug: #1917457
Change-Id: I62f35dce338ae186a217dd1d0a141d3a737243a0
(cherry picked from commit 4d2d86e0df434ee25a508aceb1ea209a0c64f80b)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-23 09:28:20.000000000', 'message': "Use the embedded scenario manager instead of tempest one

While waiting for tempest scenario manager to stabilize its API,
a copy of it has been imported, so make sure to use it and to not
rely on tempest's one (whose API is changing during the stabilization
process, so it may break anytime).

Just one file needs to change its imports.
At the same time, fix the import order for another file.

Change-Id: I29c4784d59151948778cad57b7db56a368ed821d
"}]
commit_message:
Use the embedded scenario manager instead of tempest one

While waiting for tempest scenario manager to stabilize its API,
a copy of it has been imported, so make sure to use it and to not
rely on tempest's one (whose API is changing during the stabilization
process, so it may break anytime).

Just one file needs to change its imports.
At the same time, fix the import order for another file.

Change-Id: I29c4784d59151948778cad57b7db56a368ed821d

commit_message:
Upgrade pip version to fix pep-517 enforcing

This upgrade fixes an issue in some disitributions when the build environment
enforces pep-517 and breaks compiling some versions of python libraries.
For example see [1]

[1] https://github.com/sqlalchemy/alembic/issues/707

Story: 2008676
Task: 41973

Change-Id: If3e5d37a42de2fb25c8034d9fdebb16d8bd21e9f

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-04 17:07:50.000000000', 'message': 'Log information about the Ceph v2 clone API

Starting with the Mimic release and the Ceph RBD clone v2 feature,
it is no longer necessary to manage snapshot protection status.
The usage of clone v2 is controlled via the Ceph “rbd default
clone format” configuration option which defaults to “auto”, but
can be overridden to “1” to force the legacy clone v1 behavior or
“2” to force the new clonev2 behavior.

This must be configured in Ceph, it's not something that can be
configured on the Cinder side.

As an alternative, setting the minimum client to mimic
"$ ceph osd set-require-min-compat-client mimic"

Above all with Ceph RBD clone v2 support enabled, image snapshots
can be cloned without marking the snapshot as protected because
RBD automatically tracks the usage of the snapshot by clones. As
a result Ceph RBD clone v2 API improves performance.

This proposed patch adds logging messages for the operator
indicating whether Ceph has been configured to use the Ceph RBD
v2 clone feature.

In this way the operator can consult with the Ceph administrator
to take appropriate action.

You can determine which volumes are using the clone v2 feature
thanks to volume.volume.op_features(). It returns a value depending
on the v2 clone api being enabled or not.

Co-authored-by: Eric Harney <eharney@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ib52879a270a4ae4cdd3cb5fc18f2b7bdbccd8ab5
(cherry picked from commit efd83675780a76422436d47c4622e22a0645cc30)

commit_message:
Log information about the Ceph v2 clone API

Starting with the Mimic release and the Ceph RBD clone v2 feature,
it is no longer necessary to manage snapshot protection status.
The usage of clone v2 is controlled via the Ceph “rbd default
clone format” configuration option which defaults to “auto”, but
can be overridden to “1” to force the legacy clone v1 behavior or
“2” to force the new clonev2 behavior.

This must be configured in Ceph, it's not something that can be
configured on the Cinder side.

As an alternative, setting the minimum client to mimic
"$ ceph osd set-require-min-compat-client mimic"

Above all with Ceph RBD clone v2 support enabled, image snapshots
can be cloned without marking the snapshot as protected because
RBD automatically tracks the usage of the snapshot by clones. As
a result Ceph RBD clone v2 API improves performance.

This proposed patch adds logging messages for the operator
indicating whether Ceph has been configured to use the Ceph RBD
v2 clone feature.

In this way the operator can consult with the Ceph administrator
to take appropriate action.

You can determine which volumes are using the clone v2 feature
thanks to volume.volume.op_features(). It returns a value depending
on the v2 clone api being enabled or not.

Also includes squash to fix unit test from:
Fix RBD_OPERATION_FEATURE_CLONE_PARENT in unittest
Change-Id: I00cd30f2e7181ea6bf9fccfe9170bee037b4652d

Co-authored-by: Eric Harney <eharney@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ib52879a270a4ae4cdd3cb5fc18f2b7bdbccd8ab5
(cherry picked from commit efd83675780a76422436d47c4622e22a0645cc30)

I wonder what's the issue in merging these patch as a single commit?

> 
> Vishal, I didn't appreciate the issue with the gate job. For my education, could you point me to the gate job that's failing? Since gerrit didn't include this failure here I didn't realize that the gate is blocked.
> 
> Thanks!

I see two ways to handle this kind of situation.
The one is to squash two changes which block each other.
The other is to make a known failing job non-voting temporarily and make it voting again in the next patch.
My vote is the second option. IMHO squashing two separate topics into a single patch is not a good way from POV of not mixing multiple thing in a single commit.
(Of course, you need to mention why some job is temporary non-voting in the commit message.)
Thought?"}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2021-02-18 10:22:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
Run npm nodejs job with Firefox browser

This patch update browser from Chrome to Firefox in karma.conf.js
becuase nodejs fails with Chrome browser as not able to access some
URL. So let's switch to Firefox browser now then we can use Chrome
browser in future once this issue is resolved.

Change-Id: Id5186f16656e0671dda7ab91062c104b2c08758f
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>

removes trusty support (14.04 which is EOL at 21.04).

commit_message:
Add update_reservation to dummy plugin

update_reservation is now an abstract method. It needs to be added to
all plugins.

Change-Id: I921878bd5233613b804b17813af1aac5bdfed9e7
(cherry picked from commit 1dbc30202bddfd4f03bdc9a8005de3c363d2ac1d)

Version 3.4.0 breaks bifrost on stable/victoria as the upper constraints
is set to 3.2.1, this version should be enough to work fine with centos

Change-Id: I6a278b11ed6d14661be87cfeee4bec03c42f0f9d

commit_message:
Relax requirement of diskimage-builder

Version 3.4.0 breaks bifrost on stable/victoria as the upper constraints
is set to 3.2.1, this version should be enough to work fine with centos
stream even if it doesn't officially supports it.

Change-Id: I6a278b11ed6d14661be87cfeee4bec03c42f0f9d

commit_message:
Disable nodjs an lower constraint job temporarily

While we are trying to fix both lower constraints and the nodejs job,
temporarily disable the nodejs job so we can merge
I6bd42b175e74c9015db803eaaff09d908fae6a10 and
Id5186f16656e0671dda7ab91062c104b2c08758f.

Change-Id: I34a0bcd2413f1c3dcbbed64c052b6e995f846861
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-03-03 00:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25:

(3 comments)

This was green on the legacy-rbac job as expected with no glance changes, and fails (as expected) the secure-rbac job. Lance is going to split out some of the skip stuff and then I think we can commit these as they are, since they run against base glance today.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-03-03 00:24:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 26.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-03-03 00:26:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 27.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-03-03 00:28:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Code-Review+2

This is the same as the previous set, but with a big chunk of always-skipped tests moved to another patch, which we can review and apply later.

To me, this looks like super comprehensive validation of our existing policy stuff. Note my comments on the previous patchset about the meaning of the ProjectAdminTests and ProjectMemberTests, in terms of how they will behave and evolve as we iterate over the patch to add the scope stuff to glance.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-03-03 00:34:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2021-03-03 16:25:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thank you Lance!'}]

commit_message:
Implement API protection testing for images

This commit lays down some basic protection tests so that we can start
testing the secure RBAC changes proposed to glance. It also adds a
.zuul.yaml so that we can run the tests as check and gate jobs.

Change-Id: I35d6b546da260f3f6b5c427a17ee3509cdc41277

commit_message:
Add --name to port list

The neutron API supports filtering ports by name, but
the CLI was missing support for it like it does for
other networking resources.

Change-Id: I4ff339e18656013218a26f045b205cb7a02dd2fb
Story: #2008654

commit_message:
Use Docker healthchecks for magnum services

This change enables the use of Docker healthchecks for magnum
services.
Implements: blueprint container-health-check
